description:
Good spot for coffee. We got a regular coffee and a cake that was ok. Service was great and very attentive. Saw a few people playing on their electronic devices, so may be a good spot for locals that want to work on their laptop or study.

I think coffee and pastries could be better specially considering the great location this place have! Cheers
author: Hugo d.

description:
Sign says "$2.50 for a 20oz iced coffee."


I order it. She says it will be $3 plus tax. I mention that the sign says differently and she says she changed her prices. The next size down says "$2.25 for a 16 oz" coffee" so I order that.

She charges me $2.50 and gives me a 14oz cup of iced coffee...when I complain she mutters something in another language and says "people like to give me problems I don't know why" to her next customer. I'm standing there like..."wth" 

I again say, while she again ignores me, "This is a 14 oz cup. This isn't even a small iced coffee....

She again ignores me, I leave. Don't waste your money.
author: Brandileigha S.

description:
There is an episode of Portlandia where Fred and Carrie are waiting for the mayor to eat pancakes with him. The mayor only described the location of where to meet him and they assumed it was the hip and popular brunch place that just opened. While they're waiting in a really, really long line to eat pancakes, they find out that the mayor wanted to meet them at some unhip cafe next door that served the same pancakes with no line or people in it.

Coming to this place reminded me of that episode. I was walking down Valencia and bypassed going to Ritual Coffee Roasters for the very reason that there was a very line out the door a block away from Javalencia versus one person hanging out on his laptop here, soon to be two. This place serves the good spicy chai it always has, similar to Ritual, and I get a entire window seat and table overlooking Valencia. Try that at Ritual and you'll have people pecking their beaks at you. 

This place has been around forever and I remember my lack of appreciation to plain distain for it because it was so oldschool that it didn't offer wifi at the time. If I would have reviewed this place when I first joined Yelp in 2007, I probably would given it 2 stars. But now that I am 33 instead of 22, this place makes me feel like I time-traveled because most of the pictures are still left unhanged, and what I thought was griminess at 22 is just the collective scuffs from years of wear and lack of a paint job. So now I appreciate a facade that is as faded as it was in 2004, which tells me there was never any selling out. Someone did add wifi over the tides of time though.
author: Chris G.

description: Fantastic place, very kind staff and a wide range of options. I go to many coffee shops, and this one is spacious, delicious, has Wi-fi. Definitely deserves more stars. Hope this place gets more business as it deserves. Most of the negative reviews are about people not being able to use the restrooms --come on people! Imagine how many times noncustomers try to use their facilities at this location.
author: Ceyda E.

description:
Order a cinnamon latte when you have half an hour for it to cool off- drink was served at roughly the temperature of the sun, and the flimsy cup collar didn't really help. Once cool enough to drink though, it tasted great. 

Coming by in the afternoon, there are plenty of booths and chairs. Outlets and power strips are available to charge your devices. Food selection after about noon dwindles, cases were empty and shut off with a few unlabeled items on display on counter.

Found it bizarre that the cup collars feature a giant cereal bar ad on them, and the same bars are available free at the drink station? Nice gesture but being advertised to within a local coffee shop was just weird.
author: Stefany V.

description: This place is a total dump! Asked for large Anericano, went to the bathroom, came back out and it was a horrendous Anericano. The woman working the cafe refused to give me a refund for my $4.50 drink because I "used the bathroom!"  She made another and it was just as horrible. With all the coffee house choices in the Mission, avoid this one.
author: Michael M.

description: Always friendly, and they'll make you a legit sandwich for a reasonable price. In an otherwise over priced super inflated part of SF I'm glad this place exists.
author: Walter S.

description: The weirdest, dirtiest little place with rude service. Upon going up to the bar to order something, I was told that Wi-Fi was for customers only. I was about to become a customer. Very odd.
author: Cat L.

description: Damn fine iced coffee. No brogrammers, start up asshats, or techy becky's.
author: Jason L.

description: I'll be back! Nice customer care, fresh and delicious sandwiches and beverages. Loved it.
author: Tree C.

description:
We stopped by here after shopping at 1-2-3-4 records Go! We ordered a Mocha and White Mocha. 
The espresso was good. The white mocha was delicious and it had a hint of almond or Amaretto flavor.
author: Julie D.

description: comfortable cafe in the mission with fresh juice, tasty sandwiches (I got a ham sandwich on wheat) and WiFi. The lady who took my order and made my food was so nice, my outlook on life has changed in a positive way. I found this place place as I was biking down Valencia looking for a spot to work and eat, and I was extremely happy with my choice.
author: Ashwin R.

description:
Javalencia Cafe has pastries, sammies, all kinds of goods. just wanted a brew..

brew. (2)
-smooth, easy sipping, semi-robust drink.
no aftertaste, not fab, but satisfying
3.5 stars.
author: Victor G.

description: Very nice place. Had their Tijuana cream cheese bagel - the thing has a nice kick! Their regular sandwiches are really good, too. I also really like this spot for the amount of natural light it has. And the people who run it are very nice.
author: Russell S.

description:
I wanted to use the bathroom and get some warm drinks with my partner. Javalencia was an old time favorite (about 6 years ago) and I was relieved to have arrived after a long walk on wet, rainy streets. I got the hot chocolate which indicated $3.00 but when I ordered it, the price magically increased to$3.50. Same thing with my partner's Soy Chai (which tasted mediocre). When I questioned the price increase, the staff told me it was $3.25 and they couldn't change it on the CHALK board but somehow they could on their register. 
After buying our drinks, I went to use the restroom and found out it was "out of service." They had no signs indicating that and it was most of the reason we went to the coffee shop. Staff offered no alternatives and I felt cheated out of $7. I had to go back into the rain holding a coffee cup and searching frantically for another place. I'm not sure what the staff is doing working for hours and not going to the bathroom. I gave the place two stars because the hot chocolate was good.
author: Eva N.

description:
One time, I was starving and walked into Javalencia as they had bagels clearly displayed in their shop.

I pointed to a bagel and said "I would like that one."

The woman at the counter replied "You can't have it."

I replied, "It's right there."

And she said, "No."

So I had some yogurt instead. I assume she was keeping me from having the bagel because it was stale, but she forgot to inform me that the yogurt was also spoiled.

So, yeah. No points awarded.
author: Sam D.

description: Gross smoothie. I asked if it was just fruit, plain yogurt, juice and no sugar. She said yes but it tastes sickly sweet with a chemical aftertaste. I had to throw it away.
author: Dina G.

description: I should've just asked for water.  The Chai Latte was bland-- similar to drinking warm milk.
author: Linda N.

description: Needing to kill some time while my bike was getting fixed next door, I duck into Javalencia for a cup of something warm, and to use the bathroom. The service was nice, the bathroom clean but inviting. Free WiFi too! I had an Apple cider and it was delicious. Highly recommend if you are in the area.
author: Jason O.

description:
I don't know why this place has a magnet for: 
1. Old people
2. Asian chics
3. Asian chic with white bf/date

Seriously...my friend & i immediately noticed it! 

Anyhow, I love their pineapple-mango smoothie. My friend ordered coffee & choc cupcake. I'm not a fan of cupcake coz I always consider it as Forever 21 of desserts (Yeah I'm a dessert & forever 21 snub, suck it up bitches) & merely looking at it makes me wanna throw up. She said it tastes ok but i refused to listen nor look at the cupcake. 

So yeah, if you happen to be a white dude, Asian chic-chaser, this could be your place :) 

Ps- i enjoyed talking to a small group of oldies visiting SF. They love murals / grafittis and i showed them some that i took on my realiable iphone. Hmmm , yeah, AARP cardholders are my groupies :)
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
We were hanging out in Delores Park this afternoon and we wanted to stop and get some coffee on our way to the bus. The line was two or three deep, so I decided to use the restroom before ordering. The one barista who was waiting on customers as I walked down the hall stopped what she was doing to flag me down. She yelled, "Where are you going?" and I told her I was going to the restroom (obviously, as there was only one door at the end of the hallway I was in). She said I had to make a purchase before using the restroom. I told her I had intended on it, but I'll make the purchase now. Whatevs.

I ordered an espresso and directly after ordering she snapped "just go to the bathroom now. I'll buzz you in." Ooookay dokay. So I go to the restroom and it's absolutely disgusting. Graffiti on the walls, water (or pee?) on the floor and no toilet paper (natch). It was kind of ridiculous that this barista woman was so intent on guarding this hellish bathroom.

On my way out, I go to grab my espresso and she throws it at me, not saying a word. it was unbelievable! Will not be back and I absolutely do not recommend, based on poor service and horrifically dirty restroom. Ew.
author: Kate B.

description: Walked in with my sister so she could buy a coffee. As I walked to the restroom, I was quickly stopped by a lady working who refused to let me use the restroom even though we were customers. I could only flush her precious toilet if I myself bought a latte too. Nice service
author: Shyla W.

description:
BLOG DWELLER CAFE HOPPER
(3.5 stars)

I've turned into one of those Cafe Hobos (blog dwellers and cafe hopper) on Sundays. Seems like every cafe in the mission is overly packed with apple laptop owners, bicycle riders, and urban city hipsters shopping at thrift stores because they "like the look of torn mix-and-match 'vintage' appeal". there is something distinct and unique about Valencia street, filled with amazing restaurants, cafes, internet shops, boutiques, bookstores, and thrift stores. Good luck finding a spot to chill on a Sunday afternoon.

passed this cafe, saw a yelp sticker on the window, an open table, rushed in and ordered hot cocoa with whip cream and a slice of chocolate marble pound cake. The ambiance of this place seems very 'cafe like', humble, small, one barista, and freshly made pastries on the counter top. i think thats the best slice of chocolate marble pound cake i've had and the hot cocoa was made perfect. 

Either Two Occassions by Ideele from my iTouch was getting to me or sinking my palate into that slice of chocolate marble pound cake made me have a foodgasm. I slighly let out a 'yyyyuuummm' beneth my breathe while these hipster apple owner I was rudely interrupted by peeping hipsters coming into the cafe and not fully shutting the door allowing cold ass bay area air seeping into the cafe. FIX YOUR DOOR!!! after delighting myself with something warm and something sweet, it was off to meet up with some friends at a different location for a small bite.

I would definately come back to this place. It's quite, not alot of chitterchatter cafes where i find those people should be at a bar instead of a cafe. 

* Prices - affordable
* Ambiance - quiet
* Service - average
* Taste - my order was great

Will i be back? OH YES!!!!

Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
I hope you're not afraid of people accidentally walking in on you when you're using the bathroom because for whatever reason, the bathroom door is missing a lock!  I don't even know if they have some kind of "in use" sign you can hang outside the door - that would likely lessen the fear as you sit on the toilet.  

Other than that I feel like this place has personality.  I like all the art on the wall (they're for sale if you ever want one).  The music playing was ok and it wasn't too loud but I always have my iPod on so I could care less about what kind of music they play.  There's lots of seating, didn't really notice how much outlets are available, and there's free wi-fi.  The service was great but the coffee wasn't all that wonderful (I'm not even a huge coffee/espresso fiend and I was very disappointed in the caramel mocha!).  They also have food and such.

Anyway, overall, I think it's a really good place to sit down to study, get some work done or read a book.
author: Mercy D.

description:
Friendly service and great smoothies!

It's a nice, quiet spot for some reading and writing during morning hours. 

They have background music but keep it low enough to not be a distraction. 

I've only ever seen one person behind the counter which can mean a longer wait time, but service is still pleasant.
author: rachel g.

description: Cute neighborhood spot, doesn't try to be anything pretentious. You're not going to find edison light bulbs and reclaimed wood walls here but food is good, service is nice, and you can spend a relaxing afternoon here. Had a yogurt strawberry-blueberry yogurt and a slice of blueberry coffeecake which were great. They have free wifi which works well. Not a lot of outlets but one of the booths in the back has an outlet under the table. I'd happily spend another afternoon here.
author: Nisha G.

description: What a neighborhood coffee shop should be. Affordable, fast, have skim milk available, and friendly. Feel good supporting a local business and getting my morning Java!
author: Sydney G.

description:
Passable cup of coffee. Very friendly staff. 

Bathroom door doesn't lock, so prop the stool inside up against the door
author: Peter G.

description: It's simple customer service to use the restroom at a cafe. I bought a coffee and my sister wants to use the bathroom, so she tries to go but is denied because she isn't a customer. I understand if you aren't a customer you can't use the bathroom. But I bought a coffee so she can go and I won't use the bathroom, there is no difference. What's one flush of your toilet to leave your customers happy to have bought a coffee here? Leaves as bitter a taste in my mouth as the iced coffee I bought.
author: Lauren W.

description: Great service and AMAZING sandwiches!! I literally can eat this every day. I dream about their pastrami sandwhich!! A lot of pastrami and veggies for $7!! Dont sleep on this spot!!!
author: Luisa V.

description: Good place to grab a good morning blend, wifi and plenty of seating.
author: Will D.

description:
Decent smoothies - yogurt or milk based. But for the price - 5$ - I'd rather get my drink on at Sidewalk Juice. 
The pineapple-mango left my mouth feeling chalky but the strawberry had an excellent sweet/tangy balance.
author: Ivan L.

description: Walking down Valencia in the Mission district, I needed some caffeine.  This place happened to be on my way so it fit the bill.  I got a black americano and it was solid. Didn't seem too bitter so I was happy with it.  I'm not from the area but it definitely seems like the place that locals hang out to have a bagel and read the paper.
author: Alex K.

description: This looked like a nice place. So I walked in to get a coffee and use the bathroom. Apparently I did these in the wrong order. As I walked in the woman behind the counter said where are you going? I said, to use the bathroom. Before I could finish she got very imperious and told me customers only you have to leave. I told her that I had intended to use the restroom and then buy a coffee on the way out. Didn't matter at that point. She just repeated customers only with an angry look on her face. Nice way to win new customers.
author: Mike W.

description:
With so many other good coffee spots nearby, it's hard to find a compelling reason to visit this one besides that it isn't crowded.

Pros: not busy, power on walls for laptops, ample seating, great for take-out orders if you're not picky and don't want to wait in line, a little removed from the Mission scene if you need a place to get some work done without interruption.

Cons: They say they have wifi and will give you the password but it isn't reliable. Second, customer service is unconventional - I once asked for an iced latte and received a hot latte instead. The woman serving me was very apologetic but then she just gave me a cup of ice.  Finally, at best you could consider this an eclectic ambiance -- a former refrigerated display case that has been retired and covered with contact paper and a mish-mash of abstract art, vintage French posters, and landscape photography decorate the walls without any coherence.

Good for an emergency morning fix, to duck away from the Mission scene, but not something to actively seek out.
author: Elaine W.

description:
I had a 20-oz. mocha and a chocolate-cheesecake muffin, $5.85. Veged out for an hour, did some email via the free wi-fi.  Checked out the Tamara de Lempicka paintings, one of which is partly obscured by a refrigerator with Snapple and some fruit cups inside. 

It's not überhip or gourmet. It's friendly and calm here. A good place to regain some perspective after two years of grad school.
author: Ben K.

description:
I stopped in to Javalencia the other morning on my way to work, and had a very good vanilla latte.    I got it to go, so I didn't get to enjoy the cute ambiance of the place.

The barista was very nice, and the latte was resonabily priced.  I also enjoy that it wasn't super crowded, there was plenty of room to sit and I didn't feel rushed.
author: Margaret I.

description:
I got coffee to-go, wasn't crazy about the interior, which is small and I guess you could describe as "eclectic". My cappuccino was very smooth--better than a Starbucks cappuccino but not the delicious art form of a Stumptown cappuccino--milky and not overly bitter.

Be warned- there's no lock on the bathroom door. I agree with the person who said they should have an "in use" sign you can switch over. Both my friend and I got walked in on when we used the bathroom five minutes apart!
author: Carolyn S.

description: My husband had an espresso here, which was ok. The prices here are a tad higher than Starbucks. It helps that they have a bathroom which was clean, but with lots of graffiti and a door which doesn't lock.
author: Mia C.

description:
Javalencia. Doesn't that sound like a Vegas extravaganza with long-limbed showgirls in glittery cuchi-cuchi halter tops and male dancers with those ruffled, rainbow-colored balloon sleeves and bare, sweaty torsos, as they dance around Tony Orlando and the New Dawn? It doesn't?...Well, what you lack in imagination is not my problem.

In the meantime, after a hearty meal at Big Mouth Burgers, Jamie W. and I strolled down Valencia - which I have to say is one of my favorite window browsing streets in the city. I mean, between Paxton Gate, 826 Valencia and the Curiosity Shoppe, you just have to giggle at the goodies to be browsed if not bought around there. Like so many others, I bypassed the packed Ritual Coffee Roasters and came upon this smallish place.

For $1.75, I had a piping hot Americano that just hit the spot on a wintry evening after that humongous burger. Good thing I didn't have to use the restroom, as that's when it gets ugly according to previous posters. I just took my coffee and stepped back into the darkness.

COFFEE - 3.5 stars...thought it was fine
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...has a certain funky feel but a bit dark and small for long-term, free-WiFi comfort
SERVICE - 3 stars...serviceable...but I just asked for coffee after all
TOTAL - 3 stars...passable caffeine stop in the Mission...so many to choose from so not really a stand-out to me
author: Ed U.

description:
Good coffee
Really good coffee cake
Friendly staff
author: Numa R.

description: Just recently ordered a Turkey club  and it was delicious! :)... I would definitely recommend their sandwiches. I haven't tried their coffee yet, but it seems I will since their sandwiches are so yummy I would have to come back.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Went and hung out at Javalencia on a Sunday night when I needed to kill a little time, write a few emails, and catch up on a few chapters in my book. 

Lots of tea options, and a couple pieces of fresh fruit to choose from. Not too bad. Wifi was free and fast. Good place to get a little work done. Can't speak to the coffee though.
author: Allison S.

description: Well, the staff appears friendly enough, however the coffee has taken on that telling hibiscusy flavor of not being fresh. They also use a cheap brand of soy milk that doesn't mix well into the coffee. Top it all off with the fact that there wasn't even a little discount for having my own cup and you can be sure I will not be stopping here again. Everything about this place is bargain basement cheap and low quality.
author: Justin S.

description:
I actually think this place is really nice. There are a ton of comparable coffee shops a stones throw away from here, but I might like this one more. It's small and never really crowded. Ample pluggage, solid coffee, good sandwiches (I had a veggie sandwich, it wasn't expensive, and it was really good). The women running the place were really helpful and nice, too.

I mean, it's a coffee shop, and that's about it, but if you need a cheap, easy place to chill, this is a good one (although a previous reviewer was right, no lock on the bathroom. That's weird).
author: Justin S.

description: Had breakfast here every day when I was in SF. Nice service, great breakfast bagel, good coffee and fast wifi. And not too crowded.
author: Andre W.

description:
dont go, honestly... its empty for a reason... 

Stumbled upon this place early on a monday morning as I was trying to find a place for brunch/breakfast. A nice mexican lady was working the counter and there were 3 or four other customers in the shop. My friend and i wait patently as this lady makes the order one by one while the line grows... of course we were stupid enough to each order the salmon bagel... which isn't a lot to ask for... salmon that goes on salmon bagels comes packaged and smoked ... its like deli meat... all you have to do is put it on and throw it into the toaster oven... this lady rings us up... we slit for TWENTY-FIVE minutes while she slowly rings out and prepare orders for 2 other people... THEN.. she walks up to us and tells us... she's out of salmon... ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!?! .... 25 minutes... while you're helping someone else... like I dont have work? on a monday morning? ... really?!?! ... I'm sorry, but you dont wait 25 minutes to tell a customer you dont have what they ordered... especially when in those 25 minutes you've only helped two other customers, both of which, only ordered one of your poorly concocted 'cappuccinos' .. if you would even call it that... the foam milk is supposed to be stirred into the coffee... not just floating, like a blob of soap, on top... we ordered 2 of those for ourselves too... at least she had the courtesy of making those for us before she moved onto the next customer... *rolls eyes*...
author: Mish L.

description:
I don't typically leave reviews on Yelp, but I just had to leave one for Javalencia. I also don't typically order iced mochas, but the sun was shining and I was in a giddy mood, so I figured it would be nice to sip on something cold and sweet. 

What an absolutely terrible drink. Bad, short pour on the espresso, melted ice, and plain disgusting chocolate. 

I figured, "ok, it happens sometimes, I'll just get an iced tea instead." After returning the mocha practically untouched, I described my discontent and requested an alternate drink. 

The barista had the nerve to charge me for the crap iced tea. No apology, no attempt to make things right, and the worst customer service I've experienced in the time I've spent in SF. I can't believe this place is still in business.
author: Vitaliy L.

description: So needed to kill some time before an event and grab a quick bite.  So I wandered into Javalencia and ordered a bagel.  After 15 minutes, I started looking around for my bagel as there was only one other table occupied in the place.  After a while the rude barista says your bagel's been ready! Since when, I replied? She said she called out to me twice but I didn't hear her.  I was 5 feet from my bagel and 10 ft from her.  If she was speaking to me I would have known.  Clearly she didn't care if I heard her or not, as she had a look of pleasure on her face when I revealed I hadn't heard her.  Apparently speaking loudly enough for customers to hear (when it's seriously quiet in here) and walking it the 10 feet out to me would be too much to expect.  That said, I will never set foot in this cafe again, and you'd be best not to as well.  In addition, it's seriously dilapidated.  And I didn't even get as far as the restroom like other reviewers.
author: h b.

description:
With so many nice cafes around the Mission, I thought I'd give this small, cozy cafe a try. I only tried the drip coffee, but unfortunately it was undrinkable and I had to toss it out.  

So while the price is cheap compared to fancy single-drip servings, at least those are good.   Seemed like an ok place to hang-out - the staff was pleasant, but if youre going to call your place JAVAlencia, the coffee better be palatable.  

So, the food might be ok, but stay away from the coffee - and honestly, there are better places to go very close by.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Cute place, free wifi, decent coffee.

what more could i really say about a coffee shop?
author: Ameer N.

description:
Hmmmm, I see now why the bad reviews. It depends who is working. A new person (woman with glasses) helped me last time and she was very unfriendly. First, she just ignored me even though she was 2 feet away from me on the other side of the counter and I was clearly standing at the register to order. After I asked for her to help me, she seemed annoyed and then completely overwhelmed that I asked for no lettuce, sprouts or onions on my sandwich. She wanted me to list what I did want on it, so I referred her to their own menu bigger than life on the wall behind her and said I want the other ingredients for this sandwich. She asked me again what I didn't want and appeared to be writing it down this time. As she was typing my order into the register I asked for a receipt. She totally ignored this request and walked away. I asked again and she seemed very bothered and I got a receipt for just my sandwich but not my drink. I gave up. Then, as I was in the middle of meeting with my client there in a deep conversation she yelled from the counter to ask what I didn't want on my sandwich. Are you kidding me? 

Javalencia: Please fire this person! She is bringing your business down.
author: Niki H.

description:
Perfectly decent coffee at sane prices.  You get a 20 ounce cup of it for 2 bucks.  At Ritual, you pay at least 2.25 for half as much coffee.  Mission Cafe, inexplicably, charges the same price as Ritual for garden variety drip coffee.

No particular knowledge/comment concerning the atmosphere or food.  I come in, I get my coffee, I go.
author: Harry L.

description:
As someone visiting SF, I was absolutely overwhelmed by the cafe selection around the Mission. I went for 4 different places-- Atlas, The Summit, Ritual, and Mission Creek. All 4 had great coffee but my poor laptop was dead and I needed a plug-in!

What is wrong with these places? Put in some plugs! Not all of us come prepared for the overgrown culture and needing total battery life before embarking on vacations.

This place gave me a smoothie, internet, and I didn't have to worry about pretensions. Hell, I even got to sit in a chair. Win-win as I'm concerned.

Convenience=10, Food/drink=5/6 and Ambiance =4.
author: Erin L.

description:
I was running on empty and needed an emergency quick bite/caffeine fix before my bus around the corner came. I stopped in here because it was close by, but the coffee wasn't at all to my liking and despite my addiction I didn't finish it.  

The bagel I had was alright: a toasted wheat bagel stacked with lox and literally overflowing with cream cheese. I did finish that, though some cream cheese was subtracted for the purposes of graceful bagel handling!

The bathroom is in lousy shape. I expected a lot better given that the rest of the place is well-kept!

Don't see myself going back anytime soon...
author: Alan F.

description:
I like this place because it has fast and reliable wifi and no pretension. The veggie sandwich is surprisingly tasty and satisfying (and cheap at 4$). Accompany it with their also surprisingly tasty iced tea and be sure to eat your sliced orange garnish as even that is surprisingly tasty as well. I'm convinced that the nice eastern european women who staff the place are gypsies that cast a spell to make simple little things taste better than it seems they should. Unfortunately, a rival cast a counter-spell on the coffee. It's nothing to write home about but not terrible.   
There are just a few little tables next to a single large window but I've never seen the place over crowded. It's a great spot smack on Valencia (at 20th) to spend time on your laptop sans derelicts, hipsters or yuppies. Try to avoid using the bathroom though, it's like a dirty mop closet.
author: Tara D.

description:
This place is sorely lacking in atmosphere.  It looks cobbled together and kind of crazy.  The drinks and food are nothing special.  The bathroom is also one of the most repulsive public restrooms I've ever used.  

Why, with these downsides does Javalencia merit three stars?  One is for the fact that you can actually get a table and aren't surrounded by laptops and crazy crowds a la Ritual.  The second is that this was a great place to knit on a chilly Sunday with Megan D.  The third star is for the ridiculous radio station that was on all afternoon.  We were rocking out to Paula Abdul, Mariah Carey, and "Come on Ride That Train?!!!?"  Ah, nostalgia.
author: Katina M.

description:
Above average hot apple cider, plenty of places to park my laptop for a few hours, and free wi-fi should have been enough to grant Javalencia 5 stars. Sadly, this isn't the case.  The door of the cafe frequently opened up for absolutely no reason, leaving me cold, uncomfortable, and unable to concentrate on my work.  There aren't very many outlets to be found, so instead of sitting on one of the two comfy-looking booths in the back, I had to sit right by the entrance (which was already cold because of the malfunctioning door).

I would come back for the caffeine, but not if I was looking for a workspace in the Mission.
author: Stephanie T.

description: This place makes a mean strawberry-banana smoothie.  Also, their open front windows make this a great place in which to seek refuge from the summer heat (rare in San Francisco, I know, but very much the case during my visit late last August).  I sat here for about an hour one afternoon, sucking up cool smoothie and sluggish wireless.  Just what I needed at that moment for a mid-afternoon oasis.
author: David R.

description: Despite your kind customer service, getting napkins was an obstacle, the clean utensils could've been mistaken with the dirty utensils, and unfortunately no one in my party of three loved their coffee.  Maybe I'm jaded since I received a special love note from the SFMTA. Consider my citation the cherry on top of my mediocre sundae.
author: elizabeth c.

description: Good place to stop in for a quick boost.  Decent 20oz iced soy latte for $3.50.  Zero pretentiousness.  Zero hyped up line out the door wait.  Zero filament bulbs.
author: Kevin F.

description:
This pleasant, modest, charming cafe may just be the place you're looking for.  Hands down, Javalencia attracts the most heterogeneous mix of customers, managing to mix Spanish and English speakers, collars of all colors, people with laptops and people who want to use the computers they provide, and people who don't compute.  

The coffee and espresso is fine (nothing to write home about), and its the best deal for decent coffee drinks in the area.  The bagel sandwiches are also quite a deal and surprisingly tasty.  The egg and american cheese bagel as prepared at Javalencia is among the best, and makes me feel warm inside.

Tables and chairs are not the comfiest, and somehow the lighting works great for the space as a whole but not necessarily for the tables, and it might not be the type of cafe where'd you want to telecommute all day.  Still, it's worth it for tasty foods, drinks, friendly staff, and welcoming atmosphere.
author: Trent B.

description: What about FIXING THE DOOR.  So it doesn't swing open EVERY time someone opens it.  Would probably take 10 minutes.
author: John A.

description:
One day, irritated by the long line at Ritual I decided to try this place.  Now I know why I didn't have to wait in line.  The coffee is crap.  Certainly the atmosphere was pleasant enough and the woman behind the counter was friendly, but the coffee was garbage.  They don't even have the proper equipment to make decent tasting espresso and the steamed milk was burnt and excessively foamy, foamy like a rabid dog. Even with a mountain of sugar it was still painful.

As far as it being cheaper, you get what you pay for.

If you're looking for a place to hang out on the computer for a while it seems like it might not be bad, but with actual quality coffee just a few doors down, this place would do better to call itself a snack bar with wi-fi.
author: Rich R.

description: Overall drink was good.  Barista very slow and not friendly.   Unisex restroom was disgusting.  If restroom is that dirty, what's the true cleanliness of the rest of restaurant, especially those areas you can't see?
author: N M.

description:
Javalencia is just around the corner from my place, and provides me with good coffee and a bagel every once in a while.  I've had better, I've had worse, but I'm always greeted warmly and in a timely manner.  

They have ample seating, art on the wall for sale, and wi-fi.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Semi-strong coffee, bog-standard flavor. As with many SF coffeehouses, think of the brew here purely as something to buffer your bagel with.

You know that tiny, scruffy man on Valencia, Omer? The often shirtless guy who scratches on his guitar while "singing"? My friend Leslie stopped in for her AM coffee here years ago and Omer was behind the counter. Needless to say, she split without ordering. He's probably long since been 86ed, but still...
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I strolled in here after walking quite a few blocks without seeing a coffee shop. I just wanted to kill 30 minutes before a movie I was going to. It definitely served this purpose and COULD have been a four-star place with just a little bit of effort.

First of all, when I went to sit down I noticed that both available tables were a mess. So I had to grab a napkin and clean up the stirrers and chocolate myself.

They lose another star because I noticed that at the bottom of my cup of coffee it was all grainy. They had some sort of machine that made one cup at a time rather than pouring from a brewed pot, and I think this may have been the reason for the graininess. The coffee was OK but a little too bitter, too.

I did like the furniture though. It was mismatched thrift store-type stuff, which appeals to me for some reason. And they had some good political fliers hanging up in the corner. The free wireless was good, too.

I'd come back, but not if I know there is a decent place within a block or two.
author: Stu M.

description:
Coffee good, food good, yadda yadda...

Hey, if you're the cute guy who appeared to be a writer (dark short-cropped hair slightly grey at the temples, killer arms, green eyes) who was flirting with me about three weeks ago, send me a message. I'm sorry the across-the-room flirting got interrupted by my sandwich. And really, is there a way to eat a veggie club with hummus, packed to overflowing, where it doesn't make a mess and leave hummus all over your face destroying any cool/sexy points I might have been earning? Maybe if you'd been sitting closer and had offered to lick it off... no, sorry, I'm getting ahead of myself.
author: Jere K.

description:
You know it's the Mission when you go to a cafe on Christmas Day and the guy at the next table is reading "iWoz," the biography of Steve Wozniak.

+2 stars for being open on Christmas to serve us Jews and heathens, -2 for giving me change for a 5 when I paid with a 20.  Coffee is so-so.
author: Happy C.

description:
Sometimes I walk out of this place with a 4-star feeling.  It is usually sunny outside, and I have a tuna sandwich and iced coffee in my hand. 

Other days, Javalencia would be lucky to get 2 stars.  These 2-star days are usually accompanied by a bathroom visit (the bathroom here is disgusting and never has any toilet paper), AND I've had to wait for way too long.  

The service is hit or miss.  There is a nice lady that works there... and she is always friendly and quick.  Just a couple of weeks ago this other lady had me waiting in line for about 5 min. while she fiddled around with something.  I decided it would be best to brave the bathroom before ordering, so I asked the lady if it was open.  She rudely responded that it was only for customers.  I guess she hadn't noticed that I had been waiting at the counter for her for the past 5 min.  So... disgusting bathroom visit + rude lady + "out of tuna" = 1 star day.

Oh Javalencia.... I wish you were more dependable.
author: Ingrid S.

description:
Well, I just got here, but I'm already liking this place better than Ritual.

The coffee is just as decent.  There's less people (which I like).  Free Wi-Fi.  Power outlets for my laptop have not been deliberately removed...in fact, it seems power STRIPS have been placed around for my use.

Can't vouch for pastries or food, cause I haven't had them.  If they're good, this place could earn a 4th star.  I'll keep ya posted...
author: Uriah F.

description: Pretty run of the mill cafe with wi-fi. Staff was friendly and the prices were a bit high but all was well. Not too hip considering it's in the mission and a nice, calm vibe.
author: Möhammad C.

description:
The employee here seemed kinda pissed off. The coffee was coffee, not bad and not good. I had a mocha. The bathroom was dirty and understocked. 

It was a chill place for me to hang out with my laptop for an hour and get some work done, but there is nothing special about it. Can't speak for the food here.
author: Andrew F.

description:
I went for the internet connection.  "Fresh squeezed" juice there is $3.50 for orange or carrot and $4 for orange/carrot.  How does that make any sense?

Their internet connection was down.  Neither of the two people behind the counter could speak English but the woman managed to tell me it wasn't her problem.  I returned the juice, got my money back and went to Mission Creek Cafe where I had an iced peppermint tea (which is unsweetend, thank the gods) and wrote this review.  

They get one star because she gave me my money back with out much of a fight.
author: jj b.

description:
not the most pleasant cafe around valencia... should've seen rituals before i even made a conscious decision to contribute to this cafe's economy! -_____- very uncool for me... but what the heck!

3 stars...mainly for the outdated bathroom and inside of the cafe. i had their veggie sandwich, and it was alright, didn't inspire me much. i also had an iced latte, again, not inspiring. LOL... 

like i said, i should've known that rituals cafe is few doors down from this joint, because i was super hungry that day, and i was tired from travelling all the way around here for an open job position that didnt EVEN bother calling me back, at all. AGAIN, not so cool dudes! augh..
author: Marc K.

description: Their coffee is ok but their hot chocolate is REALLY good.   I usually like whip cream on mine but they were out and it still tasted great.  Like other yelpers have said, the space is small and cozy and it's nice to hang out in, especially on a cold winter day.  The wi-fi is nice too.
author: Swetha G.

description:
i like this place very much. im a big fan of smoothies when ive got a mean hangover, so one morning before work (at another cafe a block down) i plodded into javalencia. at first i thought the prices sounded a little high but i gave in and ordered a strawberry-peach smoothie. mmmm. i definitely got my moneys worth.
its a clean cafe with a laid-back atmosphere and friendly staff. i even decided to apply after i spoke with the woman serving me. (if i get hired ill tell you where i work now, and why you shouldnt go there.)
javalencia gets stars for art, atmosphere, wifi, and a killer smoothie that relived my hungry, angry, achy hungoverness.
Go!
author: Becca M.

description: While they might have some nice and original artwork lacing the walls at the Javalencia Cafe, I was definitely not impressed by their coffee. My suggestion is go ahead and spend the extra dollar to get your soy latte at Ritual. You won't regret it.
author: Kate A.

description: I love this place, dark and chill.  The service is great, and the coffee is good.  Also, the price for the size works well!  Check them out.....
author: Matt S.

description:
Came here to study.. was not impressed.

This is in the Mission. I expect good music. 

The radio was tuned to some god awful station that played Mariah Carey, Backstreet Boys, and other 90s awfulness. 

Got a pastry. Pastry was stale.
author: A K.

description: Updateeeeeeeeee.  I went back for a turkey club on wheat with cheddar cheese.  Came out to $6.25 but seriously, it was about the size of my head.  I could only finish half, and I can eat A LOT.  1 star for size, but that's it.  The quality of the turkey seemed like standard packaged deli meat.  I'll only go back here if I'm starving and not too picky about quality.
author: Meh M.

description: Great pupusas and tamales.  And the veggie sandwich is a giant salad, on bread.
author: Randy F.

description: This place is a pretty standard issue Mission cafe minus the crowds. Plus one star for having ice cold diet coke and yummy chocolate chip cookies, minus one star for the flaky wifi. I like the ambiance, it is a little funky, but prefer the other Javalencia down on 3rd Street. It has a warmer style.
author: Cameron K.

description:
coffee seemed somewhat sub-par.  the cashier/barista seemed unhappy that we were there and ordering food/drinks.

an extra star because we had this brownie/cheesecake muffin that was actually pretty tasty.

if you're thirsty for coffee, there are plenty other places in the mission to get your fix.  i would recommend going to them.
author: Lily B.

description: Javalencia is a great spot for a cup of solid coffee and a bagel with lox.  The prices can't be beat, and the service is some of the nicest in town.
author: Brian L.

description: I'm not a coffee drinker at all, so I can't vouch for their mocha-chino-latte-with-soy-whatnots, but they do make a mean cup of hot chocolate or English Breakfast tea.  I have also had perfectly acceptable sandwiches for cheap here, and as long as you're pretty confident in your teeth and can handle the sugar rush, the Rice Krispy bars dipped 1/3 of the way in chocolate are pleasantly indulgent.
author: Jude F.

description:
So the coffee was alright. But. Apparently the bathroom door doesn't lock, and there is no sign telling you this. I tried to pee and I walked in on a woman taking a shit. Oops. I almost died of embarrassment.

I mentioned to the cashier that perhaps they ought to fix the lock, or at least put a sign on the door suggesting you knock, but she just sort of vaguely smiled and said she knew about the problem.
author: Frank T.

description: My first review is of the cafe whose computer I'm sitting at to sign up for Yelp. Step off the busy catwalk of hip-beyond-repair Valencia Street to sip coffee at this dark, warm, humble little joint. I've only had their house coffee, which is good enough, and a bagel with hummous and avocado, which was cheap ($2.50) and of above-average quality. Just don't order a 'small' of anything here -- they take the term literally. I had trouble maintaining my dignity swaggering back out to the street with a cup no larger than my pinky.
author: Davi M.

description: Oh my Jesus - I think I just found a match for the best sandwich in the Mission list that I have been compiling inside my head. I thought I was making a mistake by ordering while talking on my cell (obnoxious, I know), but whatever I lacked in direction they superceded with skill. The veggie delight (as I will think of it, fondly, from now on) was incredibly delicious and satisfying. I am a big fan of poppy-seed bread, but didn't know that it existed outside of Specialty's. And the avocado was so fresh it melted in my mouth. MMMMM. I will definitely be back for more!
author: julia r.

description: There's good service and food at this cafe, but the coffee's definitely nothing to write home about.  The dirty mismatched dining set chairs also dissuade me from wanting to stay for very long.  It's more of a place to get a bite to eat than a place to relax.
author: Marsha Z.

description: It's been a long night...I barely slept at a friend's house. We woke up looking for a fresh brunch and we happened to stop by this place for a sandwich and to my surprise it was delicious. I had a tuna sandwich with everything you can imagine (pickles, beans sprouts, onion, lettuce and tomato). I'm serious, as my friend said, there were at least two cans of tuna in that sandwich, it was exploding and it was easy to handle!! I know there's some magic for that. Final note, it was even cheap... Thumbs up.
author: Dario B.

description: This isn't really a place to come for the coffee or the friendly staff or to get work done or for the wi-fi.  My bf was able to get on sitting at the window but my Vaio got no signal a few feet away.  I suppose the remaining reasons to come would be to use their computers for the Internet or to buy something to use the restroom (which was functional but didn't have paper towels for the 3 hours I was there) or to rest your feet, in which case the coffee is ok.  We had been walking from 16th St. and all the other places seemed far b/c my bf had injured his ankle, but in hindsight it would've totally been worth the extra blocks!
author: Erica Y.

description: I have stopped in this place twice, and I have been extremely upset about the service at this coffee shop.  In a town where there are coffee shops on every corner, no business can afford to have service that is not friendly or helpful.  To make matters worse, I used the ATM in their location, and it shorted my cash!  When I told them what happend and asked if I could use their phone to call the ATM company (I guess I'm the last person in the USA who doesn't have a cell phone), the person working there told me it happens all the time, but would not let me use her phone to call my bank or the ATM company!  I will never set foot in this coffee shop again, and I highly recommend others try one of the other plentiful and wonderful coffee shops available in SF.  And whatever you do, don't use the ATM!
author: Jody Y.

description: the coffee's just not that great here, and the service can be unreliable. But they have a large food menu as well as smoothies, so at least they're trying. Considering how close they are to so many other great cafes, though, I'd say it's time to ditch the Java, which they don't do well, and focus on something that they can.
author: Jennifer T.

description: My brother d and his good friend g were passing thru sf on their way back home to LA the day after xmas and since g had never been there before, we drove around to show it to her. I was showing them both mission for the first time, and g had the idea to go try out a sf-ish coffeeshop. If you don't remember, the day after xmas was FREEZING so between that and the fact that most ppl were away still celebrating their holiday, it was desserted. We randomly drove by this place and decided to go in. first of all, the door did not close. I tried it, d tried it, g tried it. Nope. It was sooo cold in there... the counter woman was wearing her winter coat because she had to stand there in the cold all day long. There is a row of stools along one wall and some tables along the side, so we chose the tables, but all we felt was the draft. There are dive bars, well this is a dive coffee/tea place. Everything was all wiggly and divey.  My chai latte was ok nothing special. D's coffee and g's tea were likewise ok but not special either. We mostly used them as handwarmers. The bathroom was bad. Apparently it acts like it's locked when it's not. It took both of them to open the door because they felt like they were breaking it. Fortunately, when I went, the door was left open. Inside it was all yucky. We didn't linger...we didn't even finish our drinks... we were too cold. There were only about 2 other people there...so it wasn't a hangy outy atmosphere. I think this place is good for going in, getting something, and getting out, and that's about it.
author: Merredith L.

description: I spent an afternoon working in Javalencia recently. There was speedy free wi-fi and friendly service, each of which warrant one star. I sat in a relatively comfortable booth and no one seemed to mind that I spent a couple hours there. I didn't try the food (the woman at the counter made another customer a grilled sandwich of some kind and it smelled really good) but I did order a medium coffee. I could barely choke down half of it. I'm definitely not a coffee snob. I'll happily drink a cup from Ritual or Four Barrel or Blue Bottle; I'll also be happy with Starbucks or Dunkin Donuts or random diner coffee. Maybe I got the dregs of an old pot or something but the cup I had at Javalencia may have been the worst coffee I have ever tried not just here in SF but anywhere. The more I drank the worse it got until I literally couldn't manage another sip. I can see myself giving Javalencia another chance, maybe getting a sandwich and a chai or something, especially if I just want somewhere to sit and read or work for a couple hours. Free wi-fi is a fairly rare, after all. If I actually want a cup of coffee though, I'll go anywhere else. There's way too much decent coffee in this city to waste your time, money, and taste buds on this swill.
author: D F.

description: the paintings are really nice, and they have a good array of chairs that are comfortable to sit in. i've only had their coffee but it is really good and tasty. performed a lot of productive tasks here so i feel positively about this establishment.
author: Sara M.

description: all i wanted was a soy cappuccino. what i received was 1 part espresso, 1 part mud, and 1 part (not soy) milk. and it was approximately 2 fluid ounces.
author: Lisa M.

description: Javalencia offers great food at very reasonable prices. The place is never crowded. Staff members are friendly. The art on the walls (for sale) makes for a good atmosphere. What else do you need?
author: Ivo P.

description: Unlike some of the other reviewers, I don't have much to say about the ambiance; I only get to-go stuff for lunch. But for $5.00, it's hard to beat the sandwiches. I usually get a baked ham and swiss cheese sandwich, and there's so much, I eat half and take the other half home and use the ham and cheese in an omelette the next morning. For an extra fifty cents, you can get avocado, but if you're not a fan of sprouts, make sure you tell them "hold the sprouts," or they'll pile them like they do everything else. Javalencia is just next to Dogeared Books, and it's nice to browse the discount book stalls on the sidewalk while my sandwich is being made. Altogether basic, consistent, and good.
author: J M.

description: Yesterday afternoon (a Saturday) I meant to go to Ritual, but the line was out the door so I walked down the street and found Javalencia. My soy latte tasted like vanilla chalk without a hint of espresso, but I could have seen that coming since there was only one other person in there. At least the Vitamin Water I got along with it was good. Always count on pre-packaged items.
author: Alex C.

description: So glad I didn't have to go to Ritual where I feel like I need to order some fancy coffee and pay too much.  Coffee was priced right, cookies were good, big and nicely priced.  I will definitely be back. ps.  My 1yr old spent the whole time pushing her stroller in a circle and everyone found this to be very entertaining.
author: Sheila K.

description: we wanted to go to philz on a beautiful sunny day, but then it started to rain (i was in flip flops) and this was a lot closer so we gave it a shot. there was only one girl working and she was overwhelmed. she forgot to give us our pastry and took forever to make our coffee. they really should hire someone else to help out. once we got it though the raspberry coffee cake was delicioussss. white mocha was yummy and hit the spot. atmosphere cute. would come back just for the coffee cake.
author: N. M.
